title: Czech language
summary: Czech (/tʃɛk/; Czech čeština [ˈtʃɛʃcɪna]), historically also Bohemian[5] (/boʊˈhiːmiən, bə-/;[6] lingua Bohemica in Latin), is a West Slavic language of the Czech–Slovak group, written in Latin script.[5] Spoken by over 10 million people, it serves as the official language of the Czech Republic. Czech is closely related to Slovak, to the point of high mutual intelligibility, as well as to Polish to a lesser degree.[7] Czech is a fusional language with a rich system of morphology and relatively flexible word order. Its vocabulary has been extensively influenced by Latin and German.
